title: The Return of The Son of The Type ID Pop Quiz - The Sequel
content:
A little challenge in case anyone's bored during the weekend. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/49253.gif)

 [‹ Slab serif font by Stiftung Warentest](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/typophile.com/node/15216 "Go to previous forum topic") [No help needed, just a HUGE thanks! ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/typophile.com/node/15228 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Bald Condensed

comments.content: Hmmm... You all seem to have pretty exciting weekends. ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)

Not this guy!   
   
"r"?
YES!!! Nicolai, you're just too good! ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)

\<chirping\_crickets\>   
   
   
   
   
   
   
\</chirping\_crickets\>

This friendly, chubby typeface doesn't fear the cold.   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/49554.gif)
Peter Bruhn's Ketchupa?

Tiff, I was starting to despair! Yes indeedy, one of the friendliest   
faces I've ever met, included in the wonderful [Imbiss Package](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.fountain.nu/catalogue/imbisspackage.asp).   
The [Mayo Dingbats](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.fountain.nu/catalogue/mayo.asp) are da bomb! [Peter](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.fountain.nu/designers/peterbruhn.asp) must've had _loads_ of   
fun designing those. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
   
The floor is yours.

That ampersand is one of the cutest ampersands in all the ampersands available. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
   
Ok this might be too easy.   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/49654.gif)
That's tooooootally easy: W!
there is no sneaking the truth past you chesh! :^D

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/49739.gif)   
   
How does it feel   
How does it feel   
To be without a home   
Like a complete unknown

lowercase a, Parkinson from Font Bureau?   
 [http://www.fontbureau.com/fonts/font\_frames.tpl?fontname=Parkinson](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/font_frames.tpl?fontname=Parkinson)

Your clue is excellent... [Benicia Medium](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.typedesign.com/fonts/benmed.html) from Jim Parkinson... (who, I understand, drew/designed the Rolling Stone masthead).   
   
cheers,   
Dana

I couldn't decide between Benicia   
and Parkinson ... hmmm, which one is   
it Tiff?
dana! so close!! i always feel lame for not coming up with cool clues. glad you liked this one. --- oops! I see bj just got it right!
okay... ... i'll put one up shortly.
Aw damm... when the lower case

Dana -- no worries ... if anyone was counting   
'I.D. mistakes', i might be leading the pack. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
   
here's the next one, which is posted   
near the lunch hour here on the West Coast.   
   
 Vuole qualcosa da mangiare?   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/49747.jpg)

okay, so the clues are Italian and Food.   
But the face is not Italian, just the name.   
It was drawn by a former student   
of Petr van Blokland.   
   
It's also one degree of separation away   
from ------- -----.   
   
bj
clue: unseen

LD spaghetti   
 [http://www.otherways.nl/type/spaghetti.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.otherways.nl/type/spaghetti.html)
your turn Karl ...!

Thanks for the clue BJ.   
   
Here's the next quiz. I would never get this one, but I suspect that it could go quickly.   
   
 ![quizzle muh nizzle](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/49933.gif)
The cap B from Virus' [Bastard](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=VIT0000002) - either the Fat or the Spindly weight?

Darn, it's not a complete match. It's almost identical, but not quite... aargh.   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/49939.gif)

hmm...   
   
I actually thought it was bastard. I got the sample character from an old flyer I did that had been converted to outlines (hence no font names). I knew it was a Barnbrook font and quickly determined it to be Bastard prior to posting it here.   
   
After seeing your side comparison of the two I went back to an older version of the source and discovered that I actually had used a knock off version of bastard named Barnbrook Gothic. A typographic faux pas indeed. At the time I created the flyer I had no clue the font I used was not an original design.   
   
The floor is yours Grant. Apologies to Mr. Barnbrook. Had I known better I would not have supported an intellectual property theif.

Do you think that it's a definite knockoff? Perhaps it's an earlier version of Bastard published by Jonathan himself. I don't want to lend any credence to a knockoff, but Jonathan has been known to heavily modify faces between concept and publication.   
   
Anywho, that's another topic for discussion..   
   
Thanks for the floor.
Is it a glyph in Klingon?
Does _Klingon_ have a lower case

1) It is not a Klingon glyph.   
2) The Klingon character set does not contain a lowercase n.   
3) If it did, this would not be it.   
   
However...   
   
The _ **word** _ Klingon could possibly offer a clue as to which character this is.
Capitol K, script face . . . Processing . . . .

Cap K, yes.   
Script face, no.   
Italic? Perhaps.

Ok, a clue perhaps?   
   
Fuente a partir del diecinueveavo siglo.
Sorry, Grant, but it's "decimonoveno" ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)
Oops, that would be my very poor
...Sudtipos [Isla](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=UMT0000074) ?

Yes, indeed.   
   
Take it away Ignacio ...

Buena pista Grant.   
   
 ![quiz](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/50148.gif)

Ow ow ow ow I know! [Einhorn](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/einhorn/), capital E, by [Alan](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.alanmeeks.com/) [Meeks](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.linotype.com/7-493-7/alanmeeks.html) (1980)   
based on H. Machler's [Salut](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/atsalut/) (1931). ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)
Wrong character and face Yves, but you got it in there...

Argh!!! Salut, capital [X](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/atsalut/atsalut/win-t1/89863/character/0058/CP4/1/), deviously cropped? ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)
Si Yves, muy bien. Tu turno ... ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)
Yipes! Settle down there Yves, you're going to pull a muscle or something. ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)

Now _that_ was some clever cropping, Ignacio: you completely   
fooled me into thinking it was the Einhorn uc 'E'. All right, what   
to post, what to post? (think think think think)

(... snooze snooze snooze snooze oops!)   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/50331.gif)

Aw, it's not that hard, is it? Come on people, don't block me out. ![:-(](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/sad.gif)   
I mean, I'm showing you almost the complete glyph!

I never noticed the Salut X!   
   
Yves, Is it an 'S'?

Yay, we have a (partial) winner! ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif) Hi Karen, how're things in   
Singapore?   
   
Now which typeface would this be? I know I sometimes appear   
to be an outspoken advocate of fine (not to be confused with   
"classic" typography) but I really like the occasional clunky face,   
a heritage from my being exposed to grunge deconstruction at   
an impressionable age.   
   
Case in point, this is the Troubleman house face, commonly used   
on our gig posters and CD covers.

Yves ... your clues point to Garagefonts.   
   
Is it Out, the Lefty version?

Sure looks like it.   
   
But why does his clues point to Garagefonts?

"the occasional clunky face"   
"grunge deconstruction"   
   
   
Plus, Troubleman probably started as a   
garage band. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)

Haha, my clues were a lot less subtle than that, BJ!   
"Come on people, don't block me out."   
(...) an outspoken advocate of fine (...)"   
Every new entry was going to have the word "out" in it. ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)   
   
But you're right, we started out (sic!) as a garage band.   
Now we've gone all smoove on the ladies and play   
delicate pop songs... ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)

BTW [Linkety link](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.garagefonts.com/showing.html?sku=GF060011X1P2&start=1). The design sports some technical mistakes, but   
I still like Joshua & Timothy's work. [Index](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.garagefonts.com/sresults.html) and [Locus](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.garagefonts.com/showing.html?sku=GF060010X1P2&start=1) are yummy.   
   
BTW2 I've always been fascinated about the minute details   
that differentiate a great deconstructed face from a rubbish one.   
It's not quantifiable, as technical quality and design usually go   
straight out (sic!) of the window when talking about grunge type.   
It's more like alchemy or poetry.

good clues, put they pale in comparison   
to the Frat clues ...   
   
I'll post one before I go to bed.   
   
And Yves, please take that (sic!) back.   
(friendly wink)   
   
'Started' says the same thing as 'started out',   
but saves a redundant word.   
   
Nothing worse than a (sic) in a casual   
forum, but especially when it's incorrect.   
   
 ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif) ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif) ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
   
I think someone did the (sic) on Cheshire   
and it touched a nerve. We're both writers

^ referring to your first (sic!)   
   
:P

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/50692.jpg)   
   
   
   
   
clue: it's no longer new

Everyone's a critic...   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)   
   
Anyways, my English is far better than your Japanese! Hah!

I'd forgotten all abOUT [that](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/8056.html?1048717815)...!   
   
(no, seriously, I had to do a Google search to find that thread...)

Two more clues:   
   
\* this is an alternate K.   
\* the font's name had to be changed,   
presumably for legal reasons.

leafing you a golden clue:   
It's from a "multi-talented Englishman" based   
in Southern California.
John Studden, Classic Roman?
(From LetterHead Fonts)

Tom, it's all yours. Classic Roman was originally   
called New Trajan.   
   
 [http://letterheadfonts.com/contributors/johnstudden/classicroman.shtml](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/letterheadfonts.com/contributors/johnstudden/classicroman.shtml)

Boy I sure can google.   
   
Here's an old one.   
   
 ![mystery glyph view 1](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/50889.jpg)

Okay, here are couple more slices.   
   
And a hint: it's named for a guy who said he had discovered the Garden of Eden (which he said was shaped like a woman's nipple).   
   
That should make it very easy.   
   
 ![slice 2](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/50896.jpg)   
  
 ![slice 3](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/50897.jpg)

Have I killed the conversation? Was it something I said?   
   
Would it help if I mentioned that the face was chosen because it is relevant to today?   
   
Here's another slice.   
   
 ![slice 4](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/50944.jpg)
Is it [Columbus](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/columbus-mt/italic/win-t1/91213/character/0067/CP4/1/)?

Bravo, Karen!   
   
Tomorrow is Columbus Day in the USA (or Indigenous People's Day, as we call it in Berkeley).   
   
This is Columbus MT, designed by Patricia Saunders and issued by Monotype in 1993.   
   
BTW, I enjoyed printing in Singapore a few years ago. I think that's your home base, no?   
   
You have the floor.

Hmm, you've made it very easy with that clue, I guess. I have never noticed that font before.   
   
Yep, I'm from Singapore. Printing here is relatively cheap, I think, but I have never found it to be particularly enjoyable. Do you remember which printer you used?   
   
Now, I have to find a nice letter to post.

I'm back. ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/50956.gif)   
   
I don't know if you guys will find this easy or difficult.
Oh, a sad lc "g"... ![:-(](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/sad.gif)

It's an lc g alright. I don't know about sad.   
   
It's lower counter (?) is very compressed.   
   
Another clue: It's based on woodtype.

I think Yves was talking about the droopy ear, which instantly reminded me of [Droopy Dog](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.toonopedia.com/droopy.htm)...   
   
 ![droopy](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/50970.jpg)
Karen, I printed with CS Graphics. I guess it wasn't the press check I enjoyed so much as Singapore itself.
The g resembles [Deadwood](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.psyops.com/html/spec_deadwood.html) a bit, with the droopy ear and compressed lower counter.

It also resembles an ant ...   
   
 ![anarchy ant](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/50984.jpg)
(I guess to credit the artist I should mention I borrowed the ant from [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/us.vclart.net/vcl/Artists/Andy-Clarke/comics/Anarchy_Ant_03.jpg))

OK, the lower counter here.   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/51005.gif)   
   
Another clue: It's from a one man foundry.

Oh yes, btw Singapore is a lot of fun. Everyone should visit someday. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif) Lots of little nooks and crannies that it's not known for.

No players?   
   
Here's the full letter.   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/51012.gif)

Another glyph   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/51022.gif)   
   
Btw, please help me out, I'm compiling type links [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.manic.com.sg/blog/archives/000038.php). Just add to the comments.

Now that is a _very_ happy 7 to go with tha sad g. Look how it grins! ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
A whole range of emotions in one single typeface...
Hey Yves, I'm sure you have some good type links to add to my _comments_. ;-)

Aetna from Ty Lettau   
   
 [http://foundry.soundofdesign.com/typefaces/aetna.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/foundry.soundofdesign.com/typefaces/aetna.html)

Bingo!!!   
   
It's yours Peter.
![Butylated Hydroxtoluene](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/49954.gif)

![Quizzzzzz](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/51025.gif)   
   
good luck
No clues?
cap T
errm...no, Cap E

Is it a 5?   
Is it a 5 from [Dead History](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.emigre.com/dp/getfontpage.php?PDeaR.html)?

Yes BJ it's a 5 :-)   
   
No it's not Dead History,   
but it's ...delightfully historical.   
   
here:s another part of it:   
   
 ![ziuq](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/51098.gif)
Is it from a Swedish foundry?

Peter, is there an Italian connection?   
   
and your avatar is nice ...   
   
Feeling Naked Without a Font

Yes, guesses - I thought the whole thread went dead there for a few days :-D   
   
Karen: No, no swedish foundry   
BJ: Molto bene, yes there's an italian connection..and an english.   
   
Getting closer.

No guesses?   
   
Usually my leads are too easy.   
   
OK, here's a part from another character:   
 ![q1e1](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/51512.gif)   
   
The typeface is a custom job, based on old ideas.
still no guesses?

If it's a custom job, is it possible it is not commonly available   
and therefore difficult to identify? I really haven't got a clue.
Could be one of those weird Italian Old Style jobs. Appeared under different names, from National through Colin Brignall

It's a bit hard because it's not commonly seen. But if you read your Typographica regulary you might have seen it.   
   
And there's some far fetched clues in my answers too. (Sometimes too far fetched I must admit).   
   
The font is an englishman in Italy, so to speak.   
   
Maybe I should've shown a Storm face as usual,   
but then it just takes about 20 sec before there's a correct answer :-D
[Mattioli 1885](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/xoomer.virgilio.it/molotro/mat.html) from Molotro.

hahaha:-D oki not 20 seconds, but 660.   
OK Mr. Coles - the quiz is all yours.

I am honored to have finally captured the quiz after years of   
absence and pleased that my 2000th post includes a glyph bit   
from one of my favorite faces. Also: welcome Erik, this one   
might be more up your alley.   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/51935.gif)
Oooooh, nifty little ink traps. Is this a German eszet perchance?
Yessir.
If I didn't know better, I'd bet my duck that it was a version of Berthold City Bold - but certainly not the Adobe or current BQ editions. Is this a photofilm variation, perchance?
It is a digital font currently available from a (sort of) living foundry.

Scangraphic left the phototype inktraps in their digital fonts...   
Can

Yeah, they did a great job making both BodyType and   
Headline SuperType versions of their fonts, which was   
quite sophisticated for digital type in those days.   
   
So could this be Scangraphic typeface? Hm ... Lemmecheck. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)
I'm pretty sure we've seen this face here recently as a new release (the soft and mild forms Oldenbourg came to mind then) but I can't recall...
Well, if it is a Scangraphic face, it has got to be [Cyklop Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.faces.co.uk/products/fonts/view.cfm?productsku=SC10253)
But that is what i implied a few posts ago: we knew it was Berthold

I guess we'll have to wait for Stephen or Chesh (creator of this   
silly timewaster) for a judge ruling on this. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)

> * * *
> **quote:**
> 
> has only escaped Harvey Hunt
> 
> * * *

Now _that's_ irony in my book: the ludicrous bugger is _so_  
busy hunting down fonts with names that vaguely resemble   
Berthold trademarks and people who might say something   
not to his liking that he doesn't notice the obvious renamed   
versions sitting right in front of him!   
   
I'm half expecting my cease and desist letter from his (most   
probably very rich) lawyers now.   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)

I give it to Erik for getting there first. And not just because he's my pseudo-boss.   
Grant had the right family. It's [Cyklop Bold SB](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=SG.101960.0.3&charSize=14&sampleText=Cyklop&sampleSize=288), which is Scangraphic's   
"book" version of the face (hence the ink traps not available in City).   
   
Serve up, Herr Spiekermann!
No complaints from me. I bow to the pseudo-boss.

_Serve up, Herr Spiekermann!_   
   
Sorry, folks. A bit busy right now. I

Bump goes the thread, back to the top of the list, far away   
from archive limbo. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)
wakey wakey...

Paul, I’m ready to roll if you are.

Why don’t you serve up something in lieu of Herr Spiekermann?

he he.  
this is probably big-time cheating, but here goes:  
 [http://photos9.flickr.com/17175219\_8703596a1f\_o.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20080829051948/http:/photos9.flickr.com/17175219_8703596a1f_o.gif "http://photos9.flickr.com/17175219\_8703596a1f\_o.gif")
Hey! No fair! Joe and I agreed just yesterday that we were going to revive the Type ID Pop Quiz as soon as the possibility to upload images would be back! Now you stole our thunder! :-D

But when is that functionality arriving, my dear Yves? When?

We’re dyin’ here...
Is that a cap Q?

Don’t shoot the messenger! :-D

I haven’t got anything to do with coding, I just tell you guys what I’m told.

a ’q,’ but not a cap... not a small cap either.
